meta.title: Create a computer program
meta.purpose: Students are able to create a computer program that meets given specifications and demonstrates testing, debugging, and documentation.

grade_descriptors.N1: Evidence does not reach the minimum threshold for Achieved-level indicators.
grade_descriptors.N2: Some Achieved-level indicators are met, but not enough to satisfy all required Achieved criteria.
grade_descriptors.A3: All Achieved-level indicators are met; no Merit-level indicator meets the Merit threshold.
grade_descriptors.A4: All Achieved indicators are met and at least one Merit indicator is met, but overall performance is below the Merit threshold.
grade_descriptors.M5: All Achieved indicators are met and the Merit threshold is reached; no Excellence-level indicator meets the Excellence threshold.
grade_descriptors.M6: All Achieved indicators are met, all Merit indicators are met, and at least one Excellence indicator is met, but overall performance is below the Excellence threshold.
grade_descriptors.E7: All Achieved and Merit indicators are met and the Excellence threshold is reached, but not all Excellence indicators are met.
grade_descriptors.E8: All Achieved, Merit, and Excellence indicators are met.

key_terms.definition: Testing values just below, on, and just above a defined limit to confirm correct program behaviour.
Input outside the allowed domain that the program must handle gracefully.

omis.description: Program stores at least two distinct data types in variables.
omis.detection_hint: Look for two different data types (e.g., string and integer) assigned to variables. Collections count as a type only if they store a different type from other variables. Highlight phrases showing assignments or violations.

omis.description: Program uses sequence, selection, iteration, and accesses data in a collection.
omis.detection_hint: Require at least one if/else (selection), one loop (iteration), and collection access (e.g., append, index, or loop over). Mere initialisation without access does not count. Highlight phrases showing use or lack thereof.
omis.source_ref: AS PDF p1 ¶‘The computer program must…’

omis.description: Testing evidence shows the program works with expected inputs.
omis.detection_hint: Need specific test cases with inputs and observed outputs (and ideally expected outputs). Acceptable evidence formats include tables, logs, written notes, screenshots, or screencasts; artifact type is optional. Generic claims (e.g., 'it worked') are insufficient. Highlight concrete test details or omissions.

omis.description: Debugging evidence shows at least one defect was identified and fixed.
omis.detection_hint: Require at least one specific example of a bug/defect and what changed to fix it (e.g., before/after code snippet, notes describing the issue and resolution, or test evidence showing failure then pass). Evidence can be in tables, logs, notes, screenshots, or screencasts; artifact type is optional. Highlight the defect description, fix, and outcome, or note if missing.
success_examples: Bug: loop never terminated when input was 0 → Fix: changed condition from '>' to '>=' → Retest: input 0 now exits correctly

omis.description: Code contains comments documenting the program.
omis.detection_hint: At least two comments in different sections, describing purpose/behaviour (not single words). Spread through code; line-by-line 'what' insufficient. Highlight comments or inadequate examples.
success_examples: # Ask user to guess the number

omis.description: Variable names are succinct and descriptive.
omis.detection_hint: Names should reflect content/role (e.g., total_score); avoid obscure like x1 or tmp. Consistent with language conventions ideal but not required. Highlight examples of good/poor names.

omis.description: Comments consistently explain the purpose of each code section.
omis.detection_hint: Comments must explain WHY sections exist (purpose), consistent across significant blocks; not line-by-line operations or justifications. Highlight clarifying comments or inconsistencies.
success_examples: # Check if the car is valid

omis.description: Testing evidence includes at least one on-, below-, and above-boundary value for an identified boundary (where a boundary exists).
omis.detection_hint: If the task/program has a clear boundary (e.g., numeric range, minimum/maximum, length limit), require three explicit test values: below, on, and above that boundary, with observed outputs. If no clear boundary is present in the spec or implementation, do not penalise; record as not applicable. Vague mentions of 'boundary testing' without values are insufficient. Highlight boundary definition and test values, or mark N/A if no boundary can be reasonably inferred.

omis.description: Conditions and control structures are used effectively to reduce repetition and errors.
omis.detection_hint: Look for chained/nested conditions, Boolean operators, ordered ifs, or natural loops to minimise repetition/errors. Duplicated logic or inefficient checks do not count. Highlight effective structures or redundancies.
success_examples: while guess != target and attempts < MAX_TRIES:

omis.description: Program uses constants, variables, or derived values instead of hard-coded literals to enable flexibility.
omis.detection_hint: Use constants/variables/calculations for easy changes; avoid repeated literals without rationale. Focus on maintainability for programmer. Highlight flexible uses or hardcoded literals.

omis.description: Testing demonstrates program handles at least one invalid input gracefully (where user/input validation is applicable).
omis.detection_hint: If the program accepts user input (or externally provided input), require at least one clearly invalid test case with the program's handling shown (e.g., error message, retry loop, safe default). If the program has no meaningful invalid-input surface (e.g., no inputs beyond fixed internal values), do not penalise; record as not applicable. Unhandled crashes or tracebacks on invalid input fail this indicator when applicable. Highlight invalid input, handling behaviour, and outcome, or mark N/A if not applicable.
